awd_titl_txt: CC* Networking Infrastructure: The Roadrunner High-Performance Science, Engineering, and Business DMZ
awd_abstract_narration:
World-class research in cyber security, bioinformatics, cloud computing, machine learning, artificial intelligence, real-time computing and other related areas requires efficient and often near-immediate access to large data sets in order to reduce the time from theory to discovery. In addition, discoveries are often interdisciplinary and multi-institutional. As a result, a critical enabling feature for impactful, collaborative research is a dedicated high-speed network that is omnipresent across a campus. The University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA), a Hispanic Serving Institution, is implementing a dedicated research network (DMZ) to facilitate data-intensive computation and research collaboration endeavors. This infrastructure fills a gap that currently exists in the "last mile" bottleneck from a research lab to the DMZ. 

In particular, the project calls for installation of 10 Gb/s switches across campus that, in concert with the dedicated research network, provide 5-10X faster data transfer rates. These improvements foster access by UTSA faculty and students to the campus' high-performance computing facility, high-speed data storage, and visualization laboratory as well as the Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) in Austin, Texas. The new network also enhances experiential learning activities such as UTSA's annual CyberPatriot competition, undergraduate research projects in cloud and high-performance computing, cloud computing ELab training for undergraduates, as well as certification programs such as the Master's level certification in cloud computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All of the technical and ancillary components have been purchased, implemented, and thoroughly tested.  This includes the installation of the 10Gb/s Ethernet switches in eight buildings on campus.  The total number of 10Gb/s network ports provided by these switches is approximately 1000 ports.

The university's technical staff have been trained on IPv6 technology, routing, etc. and we have sufficient personnel available to support this technology.

In addition to the implementation, training and testing, university staff have also performed and documented the performance benchmarks on the new science DMZ network that show improved data transfer rates on the 10Gb/s high speed research network.  These benchmarks show a dramatic increase in data transfer rates as compared to the 1Gb/s university network. 

Security policies and operational procedures have been developed for secure and proper use of the science DMZ network.  These policies and procedures will ensure the highest throughput rate for data transfers.

COVID-19 severely interrupted the progress of this project on multiple occasions.  As a result, we are not currently able to provide any specific use cases regarding research or academic endeavors.   

However, we plan to continue progress on this high-speed network by using university funds to connect faculty researchers and research labs to this new network.
